newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil govt knows nothing of Trieste coffee ruling.
newsitem.headline: Brazil govt knows nothing of Trieste coffee ruling.

text.p: A senior Brazilian commodities official Wednesday said the Ministry of Industry and Commerce knew nothing about market talk that an Italian court had ruled against Brazil over the so-called Operation London Terminal.
Traders reported talk that a court in Italy has ruled Brazil had to compensate exporters for losses made in the 1986 operation, more commonly known as Operation Patricia.
"I know nothing about this," said Mauricio Assis, head of the primary commodities department at the Ministry of Industry and Commerce.
Operation Patricia involved 338,739 60-kg bags of coffee, currently stored in a warehouse in Trieste.

Operation Patricia was authorized by the Brazilian government in 1986 when a group of trading houses bought futures contracts on the London coffee futures market in order to boost world prices, according to coffee sources.
The idea was to maximize Brazil's revenue from exports which were sharply down that year because of a drought.
In theory, the trade houses were to be paid back either in coffee or in cash by the government.

But the government only paid firms some $15 million at the beginning of 1987, supposedly only one-tenth of what they were owed, as well as giving as a guarantee the coffee stored in Trieste, market sources said.
In April, Assis' predecessor at the ministry, Luiz Milton Veloso Costa, said he believed a solution was near.
